Turning to gasoline, Richard, what were gasoline sales last year? And how are you feeling about the profitability of that category into fiscal '11?

Chuck, I don't have the exact number, roughly about $6 billion. Gas, if I had to say anything about the gas business, it has been ever increasing profitable in terms of dollars. And even from the beginning of time while there have been quarters where we make money and quarters when we lose money on a full P&L basis, the total on any rolling 12-month period since the gasoline inception were profitable. And fiscal '10 was our most profitable year, and fiscal '09 was the most profitable the year before that. It causes heartburn occasionally.

The other thing I'll say about the gas business is that relatively speaking, the level of a good month – a good week and a bad week in terms of P&L is not as extreme. A bad week a couple years ago used to mean 3 million of loss; a good week, five or six. A bad week today is less than 3 million and a good week is 10. There aren't many of those, by the way. So it's a little less volatile and a little more positive. But nonetheless, it requires a thick stomach lining. But again, beyond that, so: A), it's a pretty good business for us. B), it drives your percentages a little wacko. But B), it drives people into the parking lots. And we've seen that time and again, particularly when gas spikes and local news stations talk about it, we get lots of free press.

In terms of sales, by the way, sales for '10 were 6.2 billion compared to sales of just under 5 billion the year before; and in '08, 6.8 billion but that's all pricing. Pricing skyrocketed in '08, fell some in '09, came up a little in '10.
Got you. All right, Richard. Thank you very much.
Why don't we take two more questions?
Your next question comes from Diana Katz with Lazard Capital Markets.

Hi, thanks for taking my question. My first question was on traffic. It has been consistently very strong. Is it possible to segment out how much of the increase is reflective of taking share from club competitors or groceries?

Quantitatively, no. My guess is more of it comes from non-warehouse clubs other than when we go into a market that was entered earlier by a competitor warehouse club like the Midwest. Certainly I think as we entered markets where somebody else had a stronger presence than we have currently going in, that helps us a little bit or vice-versa.

I think probably the biggest thing that has helped us in the last two years is when the economy really hit the fan and people were not eating out as much. I'm not just talking about the fancy business steak houses, I'm talking about the reasonably priced – the family of four or five that was going out four nights a week to eat dinner for $80 or $90. As that got hurt, who got helped? The supermarkets and Costco.

And again, I've said before, as the economy was heading south very fast in late '08 and early '09, we really didn't know. Was this going to be a help or hurt to us from the standpoint of frequency because are people less likely to schlep an extra five miles? Are they less likely to go to a place where they love but they know they're going to spend more than they want to? We found out the answer and thankfully it was yes, they are going to go there. And yes they will temper their purchases of big ticket items for a while. But at the same token, they are coming in. They are buying more food. And as long as they're coming in, they're buying something incrementally. And maybe it's something that's $30 and $40, not $500, but they're doing it.

Great. And then could you also elaborate a little bit more on what you're doing specifically in the merchandise categories within softlines to continue to drive such strong comps? You mentioned also increasing inventory buys in apparel for holidays. Is that increasing private label? Are you looking at increasing more branded fashion basics?

It's really an item business. Within apparel, it's certainly – we had a big increase last year because as late '08 hit, there were lots of high end brands. For the most part, we maintained good relationships with those new vendors that had sold us directly for the first time. But incrementally there's not a lot of new. But we are also more aggressive on what we buy.

This is a small number to our company, but there's an item for kids. And it's an item that – I'm not trying to be cute, but I haven't got permission to tell the specifics of it. But if you think about – this goes back a couple months ago as we were looking at the seasonal apparel items or not even seasonal but just kids clothes for back-to-school. And there were items that retail for $20 to $35 in traditional retail stores, branded well known items, that we're making commitments on single items of six and seven – or 400,000 to 600,000 units of an item where we're going be instead of 29.99 or 34.99, we're going to be at 14.99 and make a full margin. So it's not just the availability of a new branded golf shirt. It's a lot of the branded basics that people are coming in more frequently and they're buying that stuff.
Great, thanks very much.
Your last question last question comes from Lloyd Zeitman with Bernstein.
Thank you. My question has been answered.
Okay, then we get one extra question. Go ahead.
Joe Feldman with Telsey Advisory Group.

Great. Thanks, guys. I guess I'm the lucky one, so a quick question on ticket. It seems like the trend has been a bit stronger. And I guess we're just wondering if there's anything in particular that's giving you confidence that it will continue to remain strong. It seems like pricing is still a challenge and you don't want to pass on too much, so anything there that you can talk about, Richard?

It's a confidence level. It has to do, again, starting with structural things like in our business, we can afford to go more aggressive than our traditional retail counterparts on many of the discretionary items. The fact that when something is weak out there, we can buy a lot of it, and those manufacturers take notice of us.

I think on the fresh foods side, it has been clearly an ongoing, continuing strength of ours. Both of our direct competitors, Sam's and BJ's, I believe, have reduced their commitment to certain bigger ticket, non-food categories, as they've stated, in the last year. That helps a little, not a lot. But all of the above gets back to – I don't think there's any specific area. The good news about us is that our $76 billion or whatever is 30 or 35 different sub-categories, from mayonnaise to tires to clothing. Even when something is bad, we're not getting hurt too bad as a company. And when something's good it's helping us, but not like the whole business.

Thanks, and then just one quick follow-up on the stores. Any change in the type of stores you're opening? I know in the past, you talked about trying some mall-based stores. Should we see more of those this year? Should we see more urban stores? Any change in size, just especially given that you're going to open 29 this year?

Urban is probably not the best word to use. In terms of mall stores, I think we're up to like 10 or 12 of them. I know there's probably five or six that have been announced over the next 12 to 18 months. That has more to do, when the economy got hammered, and if you think about a traditional mall which had four anchors, two department stores and in many cases now are owned by the same parent, and a Sears and JCPenney. And in some cases one of those two have finished their lease and closed. Not a lot of that, but there has been a little of that too. And needless to say, malls have struggled. And so we tend to be the one new thing that we can bring to that parking lot that are high-end destination shoppers. And so again, it's not earth changing in terms of the numbers, as a percentage of our total units, but it's a positive.

In terms of footprint, because certainly what we do in places like Korea and Taiwan and Japan are a lot different than what we do in the U.S. Several of those units are $50 million-plus capital requirements rather than 30-plus. And it has to do more with the fact that it's a much smaller footprint. And at 140,000 to 150,000 feet of retail might be spread 70,000 on each of two floors with three or floors of parking above and below it. But that being said, Jim and Jeff Brotman, and Jeff of course runs real estate here, our co-founder and Chairman. But Jim and Jeff are constantly telling our real estate people, don't bring me a double-decker parking lot in Atlanta or whatever because it is more expensive and it's more operating expensive, and let's be disciplined about it.

So I think it's less about – in terms of size of units in general, I think our prototype still is in that 140 acre range. We've done a few 160s. And we're also, Jim is making them look. Jim and Craig are making everybody look at, in some markets, 140s. We don't have to go crazy sometimes. So there's no big pendulum shift, though, here.
All right, that's helpful. Thanks and good luck with this quarter.

Thank you, everyone. We're in budget meetings most of the day, which just coincides with every four weeks we have a two-day budget meeting, so Jeff and I and Bob will be in that. We'll take a break every hour, hour and a half to hear a few calls, but today it will be a lot more returning calls tomorrow. Thank you very much.
This concludes today's conference call. You may now disconnect.
